summary: This is an urgent email chain from August 11-12, 2019, between federal prosecutors and law enforcement officials, coordinating the immediate interviews of multiple Bureau of Prisons staff following Jeffrey Epstein's death. The emails discuss logistics, legal procedures (Miranda warnings, subpoenas), and the authority to compel testimony.

persons.name: Donaleski, Rebekah
persons.role: Federal Prosecutor (US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York)
persons.context: Author of an email on August 11, 2019, instructing the urgent scheduling of interviews with Bureau of Prisons staff, requiring them to be Mirandized and given warnings.

persons.name: Amanda
persons.context: Mentioned as having been discussed with regarding the need to interview people; likely a prosecutor or supervisor in the US Attorney's Office.

connections.description: Collaborated on planning urgent interviews of Bureau of Prisons staff following Epstein's death.

events.title: Planned Interviews of BOP Staff
events.description: Urgent scheduling of interviews with at least 10 Bureau of Prisons staff members (including duty officers and shift supervisors) following Jeffrey Epstein's death.

keyFacts: The emails were sent on August 11-12, 2019, immediately following Jeffrey Epstein's death in federal custody.
Federal prosecutors urgently sought to interview at least 10 Bureau of Prisons staff members, indicating a rapid investigation into the circumstances of Epstein's death.
The interviews required FBI agents (two per interview), Miranda warnings, and subpoenas, suggesting a criminal investigation into potential misconduct or negligence.
A legal question was raised about whether the Office of the Inspector General (OIG) could compel testimony from BOP staff under a federal contract, versus the prosecutors' authority.
The document reveals the immediate, coordinated response between the US Attorney's Office (SDNY), the FBI, and the DOJ OIG to investigate Epstein's death.
